message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of a severe headache with associated vomiting and difficulty walking, especially after a fall, suggests intracranial hemorrhage. The localization of the headache to the back of the head, minor weakness of the facial muscles, and ataxic gait suggest cerebellar hemorrhage. The pending non-contrast CT scan of the head will confirm the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient experienced a sudden and severe headache and has symptoms of vomiting, difficulty walking, and neurological deficits. The location of the headache in the back of the head and the ataxic gait point towards a cerebellar hemorrhage, which is a common cause of these symptoms. The nystagmus and abnormal heel to shin exam also suggest a cerebellar lesion. The other options do not fit the clinical picture as well.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden and severe headache, vomiting, difficulty walking, and neurological exam suggest a possible cerebral hemorrhage. The localization of the headache to the back of his head suggests a cerebellar hemorrhage. A CT scan can provide more accurate diagnosis.

We refer to the Merck Manual for help. The patient's symptoms, including sudden and severe headache, vomiting, difficulty walking, and ataxia, suggest a cerebellar hemorrhage. The minor weakness of the muscles of facial expression, notable nystagmus, and abnormal heel-to-shin exam also indicate cerebellar involvement. The fact that the patient localizes the headache to the back of his head further supports this diagnosis. Subarachnoid hemorrhages typically present with a sudden, severe headache that peaks within seconds to minutes and is often described as "the worst headache of my life." Pontine and thalamic hemorrhages may present with different neurological deficits, such as cranial nerve palsies or hemiparesis. The non-contrast CT scan of the head will help confirm the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden and severe headache along with vomiting and difficulty walking following a fall raise the possibility of intracranial hemorrhage. The localization of the headache to the back of the head, nystagmus, ataxia, and abnormal heel to shin exam suggest cerebellar hemorrhage. The other options, including pontine hemorrhage, thalamic hemorrhage, and subarachnoid hemorrhage, have different neurological findings. The non-contrast CT scan can confirm the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden and severe headache, vomiting, and difficulty walking after a fall suggest a cerebellar hemorrhage. The patient's neurological exam findings also support this diagnosis, specifically the ataxia, nystagmus, and abnormal heel to shin exam. A non-contrast CT scan of the head can confirm the diagnosis. Pontine hemorrhage typically presents with rapid onset of coma, quadriplegia, and pinpoint pupils, while thalamic hemorrhage commonly presents with numbness or weakness on one side of the body. Subarachnoid hemorrhage typically presents with a sudden, severe headache and neck stiffness.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden and severe headache, vomiting, and difficulty walking suggest a bleeding in the brain. The localization of the headache to the back of the head suggests a cerebellar hemorrhage, which can affect coordination and cause ataxia. The nystagmus and weakness of facial muscles also suggest cerebellar involvement. A non-contrast CT scan of the head can confirm the diagnosis. Pontine hemorrhage can cause similar symptoms but usually have rapid progression to coma. Thalamic hemorrhage can lead to sensory deficits, and subarachnoid hemorrhage usually presents with sudden onset of "the worst headache of my life."

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden and severe headache, vomiting, difficulty walking, and ataxic gait suggest a cerebellar hemorrhage. The nystagmus and abnormal heel to shin exam support this diagnosis. A non-contrast CT scan of the head is pending to confirm the diagnosis. Pontine hemorrhage can cause similar symptoms but would produce an acute onset of locked-in syndrome. Thalamic hemorrhage would be more likely to cause sensory disturbances. Subarachnoid hemorrhage would also cause a sudden onset headache, but the additional neurological findings do not support this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden and severe headache, along with vomiting and difficulty walking after a fall, suggests the possibility of a bleed in the brain. The location of the headache and the neurological findings, such as nystagmus and ataxia, suggest a cerebellar hemorrhage. The pending CT scan will help confirm the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden and severe headache, vomiting, difficulty walking, and neurological abnormalities suggest a cerebellar hemorrhage. The location of the patient's headache (back of the head) and the ataxia on gait examination are also suggestive of a cerebellar lesion. A non-contrast CT scan of the head is pending to confirm the diagnosis. Pontine hemorrhage is unlikely as it would not cause the patient's headache or facial weakness, and thalamic hemorrhage typically presents with sensory or motor deficits but not ataxia. Subarachnoid hemorrhage would be characterized by a different distribution of neurological symptoms, such as neck stiffness, seizure, or altered mental status.
